Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A potential new dust source in the southern hemisphere: Reactivation of the Kalahari dunes
Award.AbstractNarration:
A potential new dust source in the southern hemisphere: Reactivation of the Kalahari dunes

The main sources of atmospheric dust on Earth are located in drylands and at present, most of the active dust sources are in the northern hemisphere, which accounts for more than 90% of global dust emissions. Although, currently, the contribution of dust emission from the southern hemisphere is relatively low, reductions in vegetation cover due to land use or climate change provide the potential for new source areas to emerge. The Kalahari Desert is a potentially large dust source in the Southern Hemisphere, which is prone to remobilization in response to possible losses of vegetation cover. Reactivation of the Kalahari dunes and subsequent emission of dust has the potential to cause considerable changes to the atmospheric composition and biogeochemical cycling of the Southern Hemisphere. Quite surprisingly, the impact of dune activation on the regime of dust emissions from the Southern Kalahari landscape has never been investigated before. Moreover, it is not clear whether reactivated dunes could support the same biomass as the ecosystem in its stable state. The objective of the proposed research is to investigate the response of the Kalahari environment to changing climate and land use. It will assess changes in land cover and dust emissions resulting from the predicted aridification of interior southern Africa, large scale encroachment of woody plants, and increasing population and demand for animal products from this region dominated by pastoral land use.

This study will shed light on the large scale implications of climate change and overgrazing in one of the most vulnerable arid landscapes in the southern hemisphere. Through a variety of field measurements both in degraded and well managed grazing lands in Botswana, it will provide an integrated assessment of the natural and human threats faced by the Kalahari environment and its people, and allow for an evaluation of the sustainability of different land use strategies. These assessments will provide critical information for land users and managers in other environmentally sensitive arid regions. Beyond the regional impacts in Africa, this research will provide a quantitative assessment of the potential dust emissions from the Kalahari, which may considerably alter the composition and biogeochemistry of the atmosphere of the Southern Hemisphere. Because of the crosscutting nature of this work, it is supported by NSF?s programs in Geomorphology and Land-use Dynamics, Geography and Spatial Sciences, Earth Science Instrumentation and Facilities, and Office of International Science and Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

 

This study has shown significant differences in dust emission from different landscapes related to geomorphology and land use.  Based on these results, we are developing a state-and-transition model for sandy rangelands that connects land use and dust emission for the first time, supported by remote sensing analyses from the region. This model includes results from our grazing exclosure experiments showing that, under current climate conditions, the most erodible bare surfaces are maintained by active grazing, and therefore represent one phase of an ecosystem state. Vegetation structure that permits wind erosion is maintained by both grazing and state changes, and the resulting spatial distribution impacts potential for dust emission.  Laboratory analyses have shown that the dunes from the Kalahari have the potential to be an important source of iron to the southern Atlantic and southern Indian Oceans.  This analysis has been repeated for dust sources throughout the southern hemisphere showing strong inverse relationships between the potential for dust deposition on the ocean and high nitrogen-low chlorophyll areas, in support of the iron limitation hypothesis. As a part of this analysis, we conclude that Antarctic dust and other sediment sources are important contributors to oceanic productivity in the far Southern Ocean. Additional modeling analyses have indicated the potential of dust emission to impact climate in feedbacks that further result in aridity. Our investigation of the effect of climate change in wind-erodible desert soils has shown that it has the potential to reduce soil organic matter content and biological soil crusts, with the potential to further influence the ability of vegetation to suppress dust emissions.

 

Broader Impacts

 

Various contributors to the project worked on various components, including field work, laboratory analysis, data analysis, and manuscript preparation, but all obtained an understanding of the scientific process as it happens in real life as well an appreciation for truly interdisciplinary research. Individual skills related to the various components of the research were also given to the contributors. Diversity in STEM is a key consideration of the PIs and efforts were made to have a diverse group of people working on this project. One black student who participated in this research, particularly in the field and laboratory components, graduated with his PhD from UCLA during this project.  Another black student, who started with the project as a field assistant was admitted to the PhD program at Berkeley to work on the project. One postdoctoral researcher participated in the field work, data analysis, and writing manuscripts. Another postdoctoral researcher who participated in the field work, data analysis, and manuscripts has a permanent position as a research scientist with the USDA-ARS at Jornada, as well as an appointment as an associate professor at NMSU, a National Hispanic-Serving Institution. Four female REU students participated in field research.  One has since completed a Masters in Geography and Aerospace science, and has since decided to continue her career as a commercial airline pilot.  Another is finishing a PhD in the Geography Department at UCSB. One female undergraduate who participated in field research and laboratory analysis has returned to the Army reserves to complete her obligations to the military, but in her last communications, was considering a further degree. Another female participant is applying for graduate school in 2017. An additional undergraduate who helped mostly with the laboratory component of the work is now completing his Masters at UCLA and will transition into the PhD program in Geography in 2018.
